answers.answer: Are you sure it isn't Terbutaline?  The prescription actually says albuterol?  The two are similar, but terbutaline is the drug that is usually used to stop preterm contractions on an outpatient basis.I'm not sure why anyone would use albuterol tablets.  They certainly are not used to stop preterm contractions.You should be on limited activity if you aren't already.  No working, no intercourse, no housework..just tv time on the couch, up and down to the bathroom only.   If you develop persistent contractions call your doctor back or go to the hospital, especially if the contractions are accompanied by any spotting or leakage of fluid.  Your baby if born now would likely do ok ultimately, but would certainly spend some time in a nicu perhaps on a ventilator.  If you can avoid that, by all means it would be best.  After 34 weeks, you can breathe a little easier.  Ultimately things would likely be ok now, but the baby would have a rocky start and no one wants that for their child.If the bottle says albuterol, I would call tomorrow and ask why you are being treated with that, as opposed to terbutaline.

Hi, I don't know about the drug, but I don't think you should worry too much about your baby. You're practically at 33 weeks and even if the baby is born now, he probably won't be in too much trouble. I think the main thing you should worry about at this point are his lungs. Maybe you could ask your dr. - if you continue to dilate - if you don't need a shot to mature the lungs. Then, even if he comes early and has to spend some time in the NICU, as long as he doesn't need a ventilator it's not really scary.My twins were born at 36 week (I had also gestational diabetes) and my DS (5 lb 11) came home with me while DD (4 lb 2)had to stay in the NICU for 17 days. So she was small and they said she reacted and looked more like a 32 weeks baby. But her lungs were fine, she only needed the incubator to keep her warm and a little help eating (she had a feeding tube so she could sleep through some of the meals).Good luck!

Albuterol is not used to stop preterm contractions.Terbutaline is, or magnesium sulfate.Infants of diabetic mothers tend to have later lung maturity than other infants.  Weight is not a predictor of how the baby of a diabetic mother will do.  Infants of diabetic mothers born at almost 33 weeks will almost certainly have problems breathing, regardless of size.  Utimately, these infants do well, but in the short term they often can and do need ventilatory support for breathing.  So the best thing is to delay delivery as long as possible.  After 34 weeks, you can breathe a bit easier, but the baby will likely still have problems at first.In addition to respiratory problems preterm infants have problems feeding, maintaining their body temps, and with blood sugar.  ULTIMATELY, they do fine with good treatment, but if they can be kept inside the mother for a couple more weeks thats the best thing.
